reviewText: I am IN LOVE with Sheldon. OMG, he is so hilarious.  I came into this show in the middle of season 2 and it was because of Sheldon that I bought Season 1 and Season 2 -to catch up with what I missed. Now I just want to own it, because everything on tv is so stupid now, it is worth buying the good stuff so that one has proof that someone had a good idea at least once or twice during this age of bad tv and ridiculous reality shows.Season 3 brings us back with the gang in Pasadena California.  3 Phd's, one MA and Penny.  There is so much going on in this show, the things they say are so funny.  But the friendship is really great, they have their clique and they are cool in their own way.  Honestly, the show would not survive without Walowitz and Sheldon.  I just love how those two characters are just complete polar opposites, Walowitz being a total girl crazy horndog, and Sheldon being totally sexually ambivilent and sexually ambiguous. His OCD is hilarious.  I also love the mothers, Laurie Metcaf as Sheldon's mom and (I cant recall her name) as Leonard's mom.  Great actresses, playing these roles fantastically.I really like seeing cast members from the show Roseanne popping up, Sarah Gilbert and Laurie Metcaf. Of Course Leonard played "David (aka) Kevin" in Roseanne as well.Great show, worth the 1/2 hour viewing time.
summary: Just When You Thought There Was Nothing To Watch On TV Anymore

reviewText: I'm looking forward to getting the 3rd season on DVD. There still are some interesting places for the characters to go, so I'm curious as to how the writers will handle this. The series finale hinted at a possible romantic relationship for Sheldon, which should be interesting in several dimensions.Now I think the writers need to give Penny more to do- we know she's from Nebraska and has a brother, but beyond that there's not much background. What's her last name? We've seen (or heard) the other characters' parents- what are Penny's parents like? It would be fun to see Penny finally get some modeling or acting work. If I were one of the show's writers, I would put together an episode or two where Penny gets a bit part in a low budget sci-fi movie, and the guys overwhelm her with suggestions on costume and lines and keeping the science real.Anyway, TBBT is one of my favorite shows, and I'm hoping for a great 4th season.
summary: 3 seasons and still a good show

reviewText: "The Big Bang Theory" is the greatest television series since "The Dick Van Dyke Show."  My son (who IS a science nerd) told me how great this show was during the first season, and I have been hooked from the very first episode I watched.  This show is, without a doubt, the highlight of my television viewing each week.  All of the characters are so intelligently developed and the characters always stay true to themselves.  Season three has been the best so far. In this age of mediocrity, it is a tribute to the writers how this program keeps its freshness and comedy alive.  My favorite season 3 moment was Sheldon's acceptance speech for a prestigious physics award.  Taking a page from Raj's playbook, Sheldon conquered his stagefright by becoming inebriated, albeit inadvertently.  I loved his joke about the chicken and the mobius strip.  It was a riot, even though I later had to have a friend explain to me why it was funny. Okay, so I never took calculus!!!  Even if you don't know the first thing about science or calculus or comic strip characters (a topic that is often visited), you will love "The Big Bang Theory" for the excellent acting from a great ensemble cast and its superior writing.  Definitely a "must see", and this DVD is a "must have."
summary: Hilariously funny, even if you're not a science nerd!

reviewText: This comedy series is basically about a group of intelligent geek friends who struggle with social graces that come easily to most people. The geeks get a little help navigating socially from  the girl across the hall who was popular in her small town high school.This comedy series is intelligent humor well done. It has a great ensemble cast. In season 3 the series has smoothed out some its rough edges and is firing on all cylinders. The actors have mastered and fine tuned the subtle nuances of their respective characters.I started watching the series due to Fox showing reruns of the series nightly at 7:30 in my area. I enjoyed the series so much from watching the reruns that I began watching the series on CBS at its regular time slot on Thursdays. I have also bought seasons 3, 4 and 5 on dvd.I love great comedy and this is a series that is very well done. It has become one of my favorite series to watch on network television. I highly recommend watching the series from season 3 up to season 6 which is soon to be released on dvd  and Blu-ray.

reviewText: THE BIG BANG THEORY was a failed pilot until creators Chuck Lorre and Bill Prady re-wrote the script to take advantage of the chemistry between lead actors Jim Parsons and Johnny Galecki. The series went on the air in 2007 and quickly became a national favorite. Most comedies traffic in stereotypes and this series is no different, centering on a group of socially inept geniuses who run afoul of the pretty but intellectually average girl who lives across the hall--but the fun of the series is in the way it undercuts the stereotypes, giving us glimpses of humor and humanity in unexpected and often laugh-out-loud ways.Season Two ended with Sheldon (Jim Parsons), Leonard (Johnny Galecki), Howard (Simon Helberg) and Raj (Kunal Nayyar) conducting an experiement at the north pole for three months--and on their return Penny (Kaley Cuoco) pounces on Leonard.  Their evolving relationship forms a running thread through Season Three, but it is not the only one.  Somewhat against her will, Penny sets up hyper-sleazy Howard with her friend Bernadette (Melissa Rauch), and in the last episode of the season Howard and Raj trap Sheldon into a computer-arranged date with Amy Farrah Fowler (Mayim Bialik.)  Both Rauch and Bialik are wickedly funny and add tremendously to the fun.  There are also guest appearances by Wil Wheaton as himself, Laurie Metcalf as Mrs. Cooper, and Christine Baranski as Dr. Beverly Hofstadter.  All of the episodes are fun, but my own favorite is "The Adhesive Duck Deficiency."  While the other men are on a camping trip that really trips, Penny slips in her shower and Sheldon is forced to dress her, drive her, and get her through Emergency Room hell.  It's all tremendous fun.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviewText: The greatest situation comedies are those that actually believe that their audiences just might be intelligent. Frazier was the most recent but the all time finest was the BBC's 'Yes, Minister'- which broke every rule that sitcoms were supposed to meet (come on, a few middle aged white guys just TALKING, Thats it? It would never work. Except that it did, brilliantly, and would have continued to do so were it not for the terminal illness of one of the principal actors).When Frazier ended I thought it would be a long time before we saw a smart, intelligent comedy again.  Then we get the Big Bang Theory- which is not only smart but also gives us moments of slapstick hilarity as well.  This is one of the best situation comedies ever. It is as simple as that.  This season ws not quite as good as the first two, but still I have laughed harder with this show tha with any other- maybe ever.

reviewText: The greatest COMEDY on TV at present.  Sheldon is the BEST by far,  he just cracks me up, the way Penny and Leonard treat him, you would think they where his parents, I just love the whole interaction between the three of them.  Wolowitz, OMG, he really does think he's hot stuff, and good on him for thinking that, as for the relationship between he and his Mother, HILARIOUS.  Raj, well what can I say, I just love him... I laugh myself senseless when when he switches accents, that is just brilliant piece of writing, he and Wolowitz are terrific together, they could even do a spinoff, and it would work.  I do hope that Penny and Leonard never get back together though, there really is no need for a romance in this show.Love it and just can't get enough of this show, we, in Australia are spoilt for choice at the moment as we can access TBBT on DVD, TV, and on cable, we are not called the 'The Lucky Country' for nothing...

reviewText: Introduced by reruns accidentally. I Never laugh out loud at TV shows - never say never.  I'm female & worked w/this kind of guy - believe me that's how they are.  No social skills & mesmerized by women & know that they want them & no clue how to go about it.  "My" guys hid in their offices - had to be forced into conversation.  Do come out of their shells in time w/effort.  Can be quite charming after they get over the terror.  I digress, Sheldon thinks he knows Everything til he finds he doesn't.  His mom is endearing w/him & he w/her.  Watching Leonord alternately fold & stand up to Sheldon - a story unto itself.  Howard, so small & all that slimy enthusiasm for women. Roj - so sweet til he gets vendictive.  Last, but most certainly not least, Penny attempts to help them deal w/life outside of work & protects them.  Interaction between her & the guys makes the show what it is...

reviewText: I don't usually like sitcoms but I  love this one.  The ensemble cast is a great fit with Jim Parsons as  the odd man spectacularly out.  Leonard's hopeless crush on Penny takes me back to junior high and the quarterback of the football team who was completely out of reach.  I watched Johnny Galecki grow  up on Roseanne and liked him from his first appearance on the show.  There is enough science in the show to demonstrate their brilliance and passion for their work and enough childlike behavior (everyone has at least one Star Trek uniform and a comic book collection} to put them firmly in nerdland.  After a stressful day, watch an episode or two of The Big Bang Theory and expect to be entertained.

reviewText: I am not a science geek at all. In fact I am the opposite but still a post grad student and laugh hysterically at the jokes. I could not imagine anyone else in the roles. I am glad they eased up on Howard's dirty comments because they were boarding the line for appropriate on television. Penny is as blonde as ever and they go a bit into the history of the relationships (Sheldon and Leonerd) this season. Some may complain that it took until season 3, but it makes it that much better knowing who they are now. I am missing Leslie a little bit throughout this season. This show is great for anyone. I love it, my parents love it in fact I have not met anyone who has not fallen in love with the show. I hoping it will turn into our generation's "Seinfeld" or "Friends". It was a great breath of fresh air after the reality show mania, cop shows hogging the televisions and gory medical dramas with "Mc" in front of their names. You can come into the show at any point and know what is going on. Also I love that Bazinga is becoming a normal term!

reviewText: On the one hand, I love what they did with this season of the show.  By finally getting Penny and Leonard into a relationship, only to discover they essentially don't speak the same language, they opened up new character avenues where lesser series have shut them down.  And, after focusing on Sheldon and Leonard for two years, the writers finally give some intriguing face-time to Raj and Howard, who no longer have to be the others' wing men.On the other hand, I appreciated in the prior seasons that the writers didn't rely on "situations" do carry the episodes' momentum.  This year they have a lot more schtick driving them.  I can almost hear the writers' room discussions: "What if we got Leonard and the boys stoned?"  "You know what we really need?  A flashback episode."  "Is there any way we can get Wil Wheaton back for one more episode?"I like plenty from this season.  The rapid swings Leonard and Penny endure show hidden depths in their characters.  Sheldon's extravagant idiosyncrasies continue to provide well-earned laughs.  And the introduction of Melissa Rauch as Bernadette and Mayim Bialik as Amy open up new and promising vistas.  It's just, I'm more interested in remarkable characters than contrived situations.  As long as the creative team remembers that, we should do fine.

reviewText: I never watched this show until a co-worker insisted that I, as a sci-fi geek, would LOVE it. She loaned me the first two seasons on dvd and I inhaled them. The cast is wonderful, the acting is good (Jim Parsons!!!!!)and the writing is excellent. It's such a breath of fresh air to see a show about a group of very smart people whose differences are celebrated. In today's world, describing yourself as an "intellectual" and as not religious or (the horror) as an atheist is comparable to being a puppy killer. I love that this group of people are smarty-pants and proud of it. I like their acceptance and affection for Penny, who isn't their intellectual equal, but often has much more common sense than they do. Sheldon is my favorite character. I particularly enjoy his relationship with Penny and how he learns that being a genius doesn't always make you the smartest person in the room. This show delivers the message that it's important to be yourself, be accepting of your strengths and differences, and not be afraid to go against the crowd. I absolutely adore this show. In fact, I'm going to purchase the season one dvd right now!

reviewText: I just had a dream that they could release an alternative version of this season without that obnoxious, agressive, intrusive laughing track. But, by judging the great reviews and ratings, the producers coul not care less with my opinion.I mean, the jokes are great by themselves. You don't need to add a histerically high laughing track each time Sheldon says "Hello", or when he knocks on the door repeating the name of the occupant. There's simple no need for it, other than the old psychological cliche that people tend be more open to laughter when people around them are laughing.

reviewText: This show finally got a blu ray release and I had to grab this set.  By this season the show really was humming like a well oiled machine. It's humor is right on target. and as a lover of comic books , history and other things the show appeals to my inner nerd. Although I was never one, I can certainly can embrace some of the cooler aspects of it. This show actually makes me laugh alot and on this season the romance heats up between the hot bernadette and the truly ubernerd howard in a good way. Leonard also finds love because lets face it , he's a pretty cool character in many ways.  But it's sheldon that really drives the shows laughs. But even the penny character is quite funny and real. There's not a bad episode on this one. ALthough I have yet to see a bad episode of this show! On blu ray the show looks even better than on hdtv and there's even extras on this for you to enjoy. Surely a show this popular needs to have the first two seasons on blu ray too.
summary: tv's top comedy is full of cool humour.

reviewText: I've heard some people claim that TBBT is slipping a little bit, how could it not when the first two seasons were so good. But for me, the last half of the season redeemed my confidence in the show from guys in hot pink dresses calling Sheldon a crazy person to finally solving the mystery of the blown out elevator shaft, to Penny's new boyfriend thinking the guys are going to blow up the moon, to Sheldon's first major interactions with a female not unlike him...they were able to create some unique situations for the boys. The extras here include a gag reel (they probably had days of material to chose from.), the cast answers some fan questions over Chinese food on the BBT living room set, and a set tour with Simon and Kunal (Howard and Raj). The only downside is now that they've moved to Thursday...I have nothing meaningful to watch on Mondays...I guess I'll be going to bed at 8:30 or curling up with a good book.

reviewText: In the cult tradition of SPARTACUS, the halls of every science department now echoes: "I AM SHELDON"!Well into its third season, THE BIG BANG THEORY proved to be one of the most funny TV sitcoms ever aired. I had not laughed out loud this hard ever since the best days of FRASIER and SEINFELD - and BIG BANG is consistently brilliant!Sheldon Cooper is unavoidably the king of the show - the massive black hole this Universe revolves around if you will. A child prodigy, now a 24 years old theoretical physicist PhD with absolutely no social skills or known sexual drive. Sheldon may be on the verge of unifying the fields but cannot drive a car to save his life or break a smile even remotely resembling that of a mere homo sapiens.Best SEASON 3 moment (a very hard choice to make): attempting to condition Penny using positive reinforcement (chocolates) - but was also open to "mild electric-shocks with almost imperceptible tissue damage" to have her ready by dinner-time.Leonard Hofstadter is Sheldon's roommate and primary ...keeper. An experimental physicist himself, he juggles Sheldon's idiosyncrasies with his personal neurosis - not to mention his crush on his neighbor Penny.Best SEASON 3 moment: getting high on hash-cookies while on an asteroid-gazing camp-trip and rambling that he 'd rather have a different name as Leonard sounds like having "nerd" in it.Howard Wolowitz is the only one with no PhD yet (and Sheldon never lets him forget it). An electrical engineer whose crowning achievement is a mechanized arm that is used in the space shuttle (and is now working on its liquid waste management solutions). The fact that he is a short man with a severely outdated and misguided sense of fashion, still lives with his mother, insists on using a collection of pickup lines straight from men's magazines advice columns - and yet carries himself as God's gift to women is just hilarious.Best SEASON 3 moment: turning into Gothowitz by use of fake tattoo-sleeves to pick up "easy morbid Goth girls".Rajesh Koothrappali is a particle astrophysicist with a fashion sense close to absolute zero and a severe case of shyness - to the point that he cannot speak in front of women unless inebriated. He keeps using the "poor Indian" defense although his father is a rich doctor who drives a Bentley.Best SEASON 3 moment: wearing a T-shirt with a small speaker and a large selection of sound-effects, he uses it brilliantly to dramatize his answers. HOWARD: "But Sheldon, you ARE guilty". RAJEH: "[playing the Law & Order Doom-DOOM]!"Finally, Penny. She is the proverbial good girl next door who came to California with stardom aspirations but so far works as waitress and suffers a sequence of bad boyfriends - and from her neighbors.Best SEASON 3 moment: waiting at the hospital with Sheldon taking her medical history. "Migraines?" "Well, I'm getting one now!"The show unavoidably makes use of previous sitcom combinations (the odd couple, the unfulfilled love-interest mismatch) but even if one manages to discern them they are used in such a fresh manner that all that is left is great entertainment!The way to truly enjoy this is to own it on DVD. The writing is so smart and the jokes fly so fast (many of them non-verbal) there is just no way to savor it during its weekly air time. Well, may be Sheldon could but then again, who can compare his intellect with his?HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
summary: A WHOLE NEW UNIVERSE OF INTELLIGENT LAUGHS!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Starting as Leonard, Sheldon, Raj and Howard return from the North Pole, this DVD set show us the outcome of their trip as well as the beginning of what viewers expected for seasons: Penny and Leonard becoming a couple. Though they are still living in separate apartments located on the same floor, the seasons show the ups and downs of their relationship as well as the adjustments Sheldon has to do due to this new lifestyle.This season is definitely the beginning of changes in the character's storylines as Bernadette - Penny's colleague at "The CheeseCake Factory" - starts a relationship with Howard, while the last episode shows another woman who will become an important factor in Sheldon's life. During this season, the show does many references to Pop Culture such as "The Lord of The Rings", "Star Trek" and "DC Comics", but also offers excellent guest stars such as Stan Lee (whose entry on the set gives quite an ovation from the live audience), and Will Wheaton, whose appearance in two episodes will offer him many appearances in the next seasons as Sheldon holds a terrible grudge against the actor.Though I didn't get to mention this in the other reviews, the series's sound quality is great. However, I wish the series would offer, for the Dolby 5.1 sound system back speakers, more sound effects than the whizzing atoms in the intertitles and the music in the opening/ending credits. For instance, I would love it if the live audience laughters could be heard in the back speakers instead of the frontal Left/Right speakers. Of course, this is just a suggestion, but one that I wanted to give out.As for the show's episodes, my ten favourite were "The Electric Can Opener Fluctuation", "The Creepy Candy Coating Corollary", "The Guitarist Amplification", "The Adhesive Duck Deficiency", "The Vengeance Formulation", "The Maternal Congruence", "The Einstein Approximation", "The Excelsior Acquisition", "The Spaghetti Catalyst", and "The Lunar Excitation". As for my least favourite episode, I didn't like "The Plimpton Stimulation" because the story ends in mid-suspense and lacks a proper conclusion. Not only that, I wished the presence of the cosmological physicist had more of an impact to the guys' lives, more juice than finding out that she is a nymphomaniac and that she will have sex with Leonard and Raj. Maybe it would have been nice if her presence was more of a conflict and if she had been on the show at a time Leonard and Penny, or Howard and Bernadette, were dating. Personally, I felt the episode was just a filler that I can skip over in future viewings of this season.Nevertheless, this season's has enough excellent episodes to encourage viewers to watch another season of the Big Bang Theory, and for new viewers to discover this show.

reviewText: Season 3 of the hilarious comedy series aired from 2009-2010 and includes 23 episodes:#1 - The Electric Can Opener Fluctuation (9/21/09) - Sheldon returns home to Texas when he discovers that his roommates altered the results of his Arctic research project.#2 - The Jiminy Conjecture (9/28/09) - Leonard and Penny attempt a romantic evening while Sheldon and Howard bet comic books on a species of crickets.#3 - The Gothowitz Deviation (10/5/09)- Howard and Raj visit a Goth bar while Sheldon uses chocolate on Penny to demonstrate to Leonard the power of behavior modification.#4 - The Pirate Solution (10/12/09) - Raj needs a job to stay in the US and considers working for Sheldon.#5 - The Creepy Candy Coating Corollary (10/19/09) - Sheldon meets up with Wil Wheaton, a Star Trek actor he doesn't care for.#6 - The Cornhusker Vortex (11/2/09) - Leonard tries to fit in with Penny's football loving fans.#7 - The Guitarist Amplification (11/9/09) - Leonard and Penny get into a big fight which unsettles Sheldon.#8 - The Adhesive Duck Deficiency (11/16/09) - The guys go on a camping trip to observe a meteor shower.#9 - The Vengeance Formulation (11/23/09) - Barry Kripke plays a practical joke on Sheldon when he appears on an NPR program.#10 - The Gorilla Experiment (12/7/09) - Penny wants to understand Leonard's work so she seeks tutoring from Sheldon.#11 - The Maternal Congruence (12/14/09) - Leonard's mother visits and he fears what her opinion of Penny will be.#12 - The Psychic Vortex (1/11/10) - Penny believes in psychics which unsettles Leonard.#13 - The Bozeman Reaction (1/18/10) - Leonard and Sheldon devise a security system after their apartment is robbed.#14 - The Einstein Approximation (2/1/10) - Sheldon's dilemma to freeing his mental block involves working for Penny at The Cheesecake Factory.#15 - The Large Hadron Collision (2/8/10) - Leonard must choose between Penny and Sheldon when he gets an invitation to Switzerland to attend a conference.#16 - The Excelsior Acquisition (3/1/10) - Sheldon has to appear in traffic court on the same day Stan Lee is appearing at the comic book store.#17 - The Precious Fragmentation (3/8/10) - A prop ring from "The Lord of the Rings" turns the guys relationships upside down.#18 - The Pants Alternative (3/22/2010) - Sheldon has to accept an award but has a big fear of public speaking.#19 - The Wheaton Recurrence (4/12/2010) - Sheldon competes against his nemesis Wil Wheaton in a bowling tournament.#20 - The Spaghetti Catalyst (5/3/2010) - Sheldon has a spaghetti dinner with Penny but doesn't want the guys to know it.#21 - The Plimpton Stimulation (5/10/2010) - An amorous female physicist riles up the boys.#22 - The Staircase Implementation (5/17/2010) - Sheldon recalls the time when he and Leonard became roommates.#23 - The Lunar Excitation (5/24/2010) - Howard and Raj find Sheldon a date on an Internet dating site.

reviewText: As some of the folks who have experienced The Big Bang Theory have observed, you will laugh until you cry... Well, almost.  But laugh you will!  The interaction - and lack of it - of the major characters is really hilarious.  The writing is refreshingly sharp and to the point.  When it becomes vague, it is because it's making you wait to laugh.  All things have been said about the characters are dead on, but no one I've seen has mentioned the little gem at the end of each episode...Chuck Lorre (creator/writer) uses the credits to vent a bit.  Some of these things are quite hilarious, and more worth mentioning to my friends than entire episodes of other shows!  In fact, if other shows had as much comedy as these little "vents", they would be more successful!You definitely want to own the discs to make the episodes flow better.  And, of course, so you can "pause" the credits to catch Lorre's missives at the end!Favorite show so far: Leonard's mother visits.  "Excuse me; I have to urinate..."  Christine Baranski has to come back more often!

reviewText: I was addicted to BBT thought the show was really funny. A friend recommended that I watch Fraiser. So after I watch BBT season 1-7.5 and Fraiser season 1-11 I see where the writers of the BBT are getting their inspiration for stories and characters. It has been pointed out that similarities in Sheldon/Niles Leonard/Fraiser. Lilith/Leslie and Amy. I can also see similarities in Roz and Penny. The Mother of Howard will never be seen just as the character Maris was not seen. The actress that plays Leonard's mom also had a small role on Fraiser playing a psychiatrist in the same dry attitude . In Fraiser Season 7 episode 16 there is a character named Chuck that acts and sounds like Barry Kripke.There was a nerd character on Fraiser that worked at the radio station that was obsessed with Star trek.  In season 9 of Fraiser there is a junior agent  episode 10 named Portia that is short, blond, and has a similar attitude, voice of Bernadette including the yelling tone when Bernadette imitates Howard's mother. I also noticed many story lines and story themes that were duplicated. I would not be surprised if the writers are watching all the episodes of Frasier to come up with more episodes of BBT. To name a few themes Annoying cricket, kite flying, check engine light comes on,  chess competitions, horrible basketball match, bullying, reconnecting with a former bully, quotes "A cat can have kittens in the oven but that does not make them biscuits",and the list goes on......So in conclusion I thought BBT was funny until I discovered the writers recycled many quotes and themes of Fraiser. The only part that is missing is style and class. It is only a matter of time that this show will be on the air. Fans of Fraiser will make the connection.
summary: I thought it was great until I watched all the episodes of Fraiser

reviewText: Sheldon, Leonard, Raj, Howard, and Penny are a bundle of quirkiness. You never, throughout the entirety of this season, know what to expect, as all the characters continue to defy all logic set forth for them throughout the course of the other two season. However, the characters remain entrenched in their same basic patterns of behavior while retaining the possibility for personal, humorous, growth.Sheldon is the mad scientist of the group. Leonard is known to remark that Sheldon Cooper "is one lab experiment away from being a supervillain." Set in his ways, Sheldon is the most set in his ways, the most awkward, yet the most lovable of all the characters. Leonard is, too, a nerd, but a more social one. He is the character with whom it is easy to relate, and he is more....normal than Sheldon in this respect. A key plotline of this season is Leonard's relationship with Penny, with whom he has been trying to cultivate mutual feelings since she moved in across the hall. Penny, however, is the stereotypical blonde beauty, who, having moved to California to become an actress, now works at the Cheesecake Factory. Penny develops over the course of the series, having reached her intellectual prime at this point in time as a result of constant access to the lovable nerds. Needless to say, their relationship makes for interesting humor, not to mention after adding in the constant presence of Sheldon as Leonard's roommate.
summary: Intelligence, Humor, and the Life of the Nerd

reviewText: In season two, 'The Big Bang Theory' went from being a somewhat funny (if derivative) sitcom to a clever one that was well-written and contained much more character development. I think that season three is a slight step down from what the writers accomplished in the second season, but still great and probably the funniest yet. The humor becomes much smarter in three, with less bathroom humor and physical gags that make it look like a dumbed-down sitcom for the masses. I'm sure the addition of Amy will also be a good idea.Best episodes: "The Staircase Implementation" and "The Lunar Excitation"Season grade: B+
summary: A very funny season that benefits from serialization

reviewText: While the title of my review has probably been overused, that is the only word that can describe season three of this fantastic show. After a mediocre second season, the third season pumps in twice the laughs, twice the intelligence and twice the ingenious of Jim Parsons as the great Sheldon Cooper. The third season picks up with the boys returning home from the North Pole and suddenly Leonard and Penny are in a relationship. Before you know it the show takes an amazing twist with a whole new bunch of challenges for our genius foursome as they tackle being in relationships, dating and of course trying to keep Sheldon under control through it all.This season brings us some great milestones, such as Howard meeting the cute Bernadette, Sheldon singing Soft Kitty to Penny and of course the battle between Sheldon and Will Wheaton. The stars never miss a beat in this season and of course our favorite guest stars make their triumphant returns including a special surprise at the very end of the season. Still, this show continues to make me laugh and I am quite impressed with how well this season turned out. If you have never seen this show before this season contains the one episode you must see. The Einstein Approximation in which Sheldon gets stumped and goes insane. If you thought he was crazy before you have never seen anything yet.Now with an Emmy win for Sheldon, this show continues to ride strong, and hopefully for a few more seasons.

reviewText: Wonderful!!! I'm an avid Big Bang Theory watcher. I love the show and most of its characters. The season comes well packaged and protected. The case is very slim, with each disc on its own holder. And it's easy to watch on your computer. I'm sure it works just as well with a DVD player, but since I only can watch it on my laptop that's what I did. I would recommend this to anyone whose starting their own Big Bang Theory collection. I bought this season specifically since I had the rest on my computer. It would also make a wonderful gift to anyone who enjoys the show as well.
summary: Wonderful set to add to the Big Bang Theory Collection
